Key Match Events: The Lakers had 15 offensive rebounds, many of which came during the first half, and that allowed Los Angeles to pour in early second-chance points.
The Lakers outscored the Wolves 72-40 in the paint.
The Lakers scored at will inside, taking advantage of a zone defense the Wolves briefly ran in the frame.
The Lakers had a 17-2 second-quarter run in which they took control of the game.
Pre-Game Insights: The Wolves were middle of the pack in offensive rating last season, coming in at 15th in the 30-team league, but the smooth-flowing offense of the preseason indicated that Minnesota could perhaps tout a top-10 offensive unit this season.
Coach Chris Finch said he felt the ball movement got sticky, leading to a lot of the early turnovers. He attributed the many of the early turnovers to 'trying to do everything one on five'.
Julius Randle said the Wolves were stagnant early on, which was evident.
Post-Match Reflections: Coach Chris Finch said the Wolves might have to simplify some things early in the season.
Julius Randle said he needs to be better on defense and acknowledged getting beat on backdoor cuts on a few occasions during the game.
Anthony Edwards said if the Wolves made the open shots they missed, they would have won the game.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Wolves shot just 41% from the field and 32% from 3-point range.
They didn't generate many easy points — just seven fast-break points — and they missed a number of wide-open 3s throughout the night.
Joe Ingles played only seven minutes and finished with a plus-minus of plus-one in his season debut.
Others: The Timberwolves ultimately won the battle on the boards, outrebounding the Lakers 47-46 Tuesday night.
